actualResults.title: Reflected XSS via Unescaped Filename in Upload Response
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate XSS vulnerability in the upload response that displays unescaped filenames in HTML context. While not explicitly listed in expected findings, this is a separate and valid security issue that was discovered during testing.

actualResults.title: Stored XSS via File Upload Filename Parameter
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate stored XSS vulnerability where malicious filenames containing JavaScript event handlers are persisted and executed when files are accessed. This is a separate vulnerability from the reflected XSS and represents a persistent attack vector.

actualResults.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) in File Upload Functionality
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - The upload functionality lacks CSRF token protection, allowing attackers to forge requests. This is a valid security issue that was identified but not included in the expected findings list.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers - Insufficient HTTP Security Configuration
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - The application is missing critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Strict-Transport-Security, Content-Security-Policy). While not explicitly in the expected findings, this represents a defense-in-depth security gap that should be remediated.

matched.actualTitle: Remote Code Execution via Double Extension File Upload Bypass & Unrestricted File Upload - Arbitrary File Types Accepted via Magic Bytes Bypass
matched.matchReason: The actual findings extensively document arbitrary file upload vulnerabilities. Both RCE findings (double extension bypass and magic bytes bypass) and the unrestricted file upload finding directly address the expected 'Arbitrary File Upload' vulnerability. The actual tests demonstrate that the insufficient validation of uploaded files (as described in the expected finding) allows attackers to bypass extension checks and magic number validation, enabling arbitrary file upload despite these security controls.

matched.actualTitle: Remote Code Execution via PHP Handler Bypass in Upload Directory & Remote Code Execution via Double Extension File Upload Bypass
matched.matchReason: The actual findings describe remote code execution vulnerabilities that result from command/code injection through the file upload mechanism. The double extension bypass (shell.jpg.php) and PHP handler bypass allow unsanitized user input (filenames) to be processed as executable code, which constitutes command injection. The POC demonstrates PHP code execution via the uploaded filename parameter, matching the expected command injection vulnerability in file handling operations.
